explanation: You must inspect the definitions/prototypes (or macro expansions) of each callee to determine whether any of them can modify the function parameter 'con' itself (not just the object it points to). 1) MHD_queue_response — This is the only direct use of the parameter 'con' in send_upgrade_required. Confirm whether it is a normal function taking 'struct MHD_Connection *' or a macro/inline that could perform an assignment to the caller expression (or accept a 'struct MHD_Connection **' / otherwise mutate the pointer value). If MHD_queue_response were a macro that assigns to its argument or a function taking a pointer-to-pointer, it could violate the MISRA rule. 2) MHD_add_response_header — Although called with 'res' (a local), its definition should be checked in case it is a macro that expands to code referencing the caller scope or otherwise has side effects that could modify caller parameters (very unlikely but must be ruled out). 3) MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static — Check its definition/macro expansion to ensure it does not expand into code that modifies caller parameters or has hidden side effects. 4) MHD_destroy_response — Similarly verify it is a normal function (or harmless macro) that only operates on the response object and cannot assign to 'con'. In short, focus primarily on MHD_queue_response, but include the other callees to rule out any macro expansions or non-obvious side effects that could result in modification of the formal parameter 'con'.
